intro: Orobanche eriophora, commonly known as the narrowleaf broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is native to regions of Europe and Asia. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a taproot system that attaches to the roots of its host, such as grasses and legumes. It is considered a weed in agricultural settings due to its ability to reduce crop yields. Its life cycle is closely tied to the presence of specific host plants, making it a challenging species to manage in natural and cultivated ecosystems.
